BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 18, 1921
SPORTSMANSHIP AND TOMORROW'S GAME
Tomorrow we have as our guests a large number of players and
the majority of the students of St. John's College. The interest in the
contest is intense both because of the traditional rivalry between
the two institutions and the fact that the state championship is involved.
The Hopkins-St. John's games have always been hard fought,
closely contested battles, but they have been characterized by good
sportsmanship. We hope that tomorrow's game will prove no exception to the rule and for that reason wish to call the attention of our
readers to Mr. Ellicott's letter criticising the conduct of the cheering
section, which appears in the Mail-Bag of this issue.
We are going to win and our victory should not be marred by
poor sportsmanship. Back the team whole-heartedly, by all means,
but don't razz the opposing players.

Everything for

in
for show
not

RECEIVE ON HOME WOOD FIELD TOMORROW

TURN OUT, ALUMNI

r
The News-Lette
by the Student Council to a number
sent
been
ing letter which has
of the alumni:
Dear Alumnus:
On Saturday, November 19, at 2,30 P. M., Johns Hopkins and its
ancient rival, St. John's, meet on the gridiron. The Black and Blue
so far has won all its state games and the cadets have lost but one.
If Hopkins wins on Saturday we shall have a clean title to the
state championship. The St. John's team will come to Baltimore
smarting from an unexpected defeat by Mt. St. Mary's and prepared
to fight to the last ditch to prevent a Hopkins victory.
Coach Van Orman promises that the team will be in first class
condition, and from the showing they have made thus far we know
that they will do everything in their power to win. They will meet
the best team St. John's has turned out in years, but if every Hopkins man stands behind them they will send the cadets back to Annapolis with lowered colors.
At a recent game between Lafayette and the University of Pennsylvania, Lafayette College with a student body of 700 turned out a
cheering section of nearly 2,000 men. Why can't Hopkins do the
same? The undergraduates with their newly uniformed student band
will be there in force. We want every alumnus who possibly can to
be at Homewood Field next Saturday, to sit in the cheering section
or as near to it as possible and root for his Alma Mater with all his
might.
"Come stand together we'll raise a cheer
And wave the Black and Blue."
The Johns Hopkins Student Council.
THE SPIRIT SHOWN AT THE NOON-DAY MEETINGS IS ONLY ONE
OF THE MANY INDICATIONS THAT THE ST. JOHN'S
MASCOT IS GOING TO BE ONE HOME-SICK GOAT
AFTER TOMORROW'S GAME

EXCELLENT SPIRIT SHOWN AT SWARTHMORE
Like those who went down to the Virginia game, the loyal students who invaded the Pennsylvanian territory and cheered so-lustily
were a great aid to the Black and Blue team. Their spirit and everpresent enthusiasm contributed no little to the splendid showing and
comparative victory which was scored by Hopkins. Swarthmore was
favored by two or three touchdowns and it was because of the encouragement which the attending Hopkins students gave to their
team that caused it to come through in such nice shape. Some of the
boys went on the trains, some in cars and trucks, while at least a
dozen footed it. This is worth while spirit and we're going to see
lots more of it tomorrow.

UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA HAS
FIRST WOMAN DEAN

Miss Adelaide Douglas Simpson, of New York, a graduate of
Bryn Mawr and Columbia, this
year entered upon her duties as
Dean of Women at the University of Virginia, thus becoming the
first woman member of the faculty of the ancient southern university.
Miss Simpson, a native of Louisville, Ky., received her early education in Philadelphia and New
York. She holds a bachelor of
arts degree from Bryn Mawr,'13,
and a master's degree from Columbia, 1917.
The creation of the office of
dean came after a year of co-education in the professional and
graduate schools. Nineteen women registered during the past session and degrees were awarded
three of them in June, the first to
be awarded to women in the hundred years of the institution.

EDWIN W. ADAMS,Vice-Pres. & Cashier

BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 18, 1921
SPORTSMANSHIP AND TOMORROW'S GAME
Tomorrow we have as our guests a large number of players and
the majority of the students of St. John's College. The interest in the
contest is intense both because of the traditional rivalry between
the two institutions and the fact that the state championship is involved.
The Hopkins-St. John's games have always been hard fought,
closely contested battles, but they have been characterized by good
sportsmanship. We hope that tomorrow's game will prove no exception to the rule and for that reason wish to call the attention of our
readers to Mr. Ellicott's letter criticising the conduct of the cheering
section, which appears in the Mail-Bag of this issue.
We are going to win and our victory should not be marred by
poor sportsmanship. Back the team whole-heartedly, by all means,
but don't razz the opposing players.

Everything for
UALITY-

in
for show
not

LET'S MAKE TONIGHT'S BONFIRE ILLUSTRATE TO SOME EXTENT
THE WARMTH OF THE RECEPTION ST. JOHN'S WILL
RECEIVE ON HOME WOOD FIELD TOMORROW

TURN OUT, ALUMNI
endorses the sentiments of the follo'wheartily
r
The News-Lette
by the Student Council to a number
sent
been
ing letter which has
of the alumni:
Dear Alumnus:
On Saturday, November 19, at 2,30 P. M., Johns Hopkins and its
ancient rival, St. John's, meet on the gridiron. The Black and Blue
so far has won all its state games and the cadets have lost but one.
If Hopkins wins on Saturday we shall have a clean title to the
state championship. The St. John's team will come to Baltimore
smarting from an unexpected defeat by Mt. St. Mary's and prepared
to fight to the last ditch to prevent a Hopkins victory.
Coach Van Orman promises that the team will be in first class
condition, and from the showing they have made thus far we know
that they will do everything in their power to win. They will meet
the best team St. John's has turned out in years, but if every Hopkins man stands behind them they will send the cadets back to Annapolis with lowered colors.
At a recent game between Lafayette and the University of Pennsylvania, Lafayette College with a student body of 700 turned out a
cheering section of nearly 2,000 men. Why can't Hopkins do the
same? The undergraduates with their newly uniformed student band
will be there in force. We want every alumnus who possibly can to
be at Homewood Field next Saturday, to sit in the cheering section
or as near to it as possible and root for his Alma Mater with all his
might.
"Come stand together we'll raise a cheer
And wave the Black and Blue."
The Johns Hopkins Student Council.
THE SPIRIT SHOWN AT THE NOON-DAY MEETINGS IS ONLY ONE
OF THE MANY INDICATIONS THAT THE ST. JOHN'S
MASCOT IS GOING TO BE ONE HOME-SICK GOAT
AFTER TOMORROW'S GAME

EXCELLENT SPIRIT SHOWN AT SWARTHMORE
Like those who went down to the Virginia game, the loyal students who invaded the Pennsylvanian territory and cheered so-lustily
were a great aid to the Black and Blue team. Their spirit and everpresent enthusiasm contributed no little to the splendid showing and
comparative victory which was scored by Hopkins. Swarthmore was
favored by two or three touchdowns and it was because of the encouragement which the attending Hopkins students gave to their
team that caused it to come through in such nice shape. Some of the
boys went on the trains, some in cars and trucks, while at least a
dozen footed it. This is worth while spirit and we're going to see
lots more of it tomorrow.

UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA HAS
FIRST WOMAN DEAN

Miss Adelaide Douglas Simpson, of New York, a graduate of
Bryn Mawr and Columbia, this
year entered upon her duties as
Dean of Women at the University of Virginia, thus becoming the
first woman member of the faculty of the ancient southern university.
Miss Simpson, a native of Louisville, Ky., received her early education in Philadelphia and New
York. She holds a bachelor of
arts degree from Bryn Mawr,'13,
and a master's degree from Columbia, 1917.
The creation of the office of
dean came after a year of co-education in the professional and
graduate schools. Nineteen women registered during the past session and degrees were awarded
three of them in June, the first to
be awarded to women in the hundred years of the institution.

EDWIN W. ADAMS,Vice-Pres. & Cashier
